text:
He put his hand to his cheek and tilted his head, looking like a peasant woman. 

“What do you want?” Raskolnikov asked, feeling totally terrified. The man stayed silent for a moment, then bowed down almost to the ground, touching it with his finger.

“What is it?” Raskolnikov shouted.

“I have sinned,” the man said softly.

“How?”

“By having evil thoughts.”

They stared at each other.

“I was angry. When you showed up, maybe drunk, and told the porters to go to the police and ask about the blood, I was mad they let you leave. I thought you were just a drunk. I was so upset I couldn’t sleep. And remembering the address, we came here yesterday to ask for you…”

“Who came?” Raskolnikov cut in, starting to remember.

“It was me. I’ve wronged you.”

“So you come from that house?”

“I was standing at the gate with them… don’t you remember? We’ve worked in that house for years. We cure and prepare hides, take work home… mostly, I was just really upset…”

Suddenly, the whole scene from two days ago flashed in Raskolnikov’s mind. He remembered there were other people there besides the porters, including some women. He recalled one voice suggesting they take him straight to the police station.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov encounters a man who admits to feeling guilty for having evil thoughts about him.
